articles.headline: Amgen Defends Its Turf as Competition Looms for Anemia Drug
articles.snippet: As a looming battle with Roche approaches, Amgen is preparing to defend its anemia franchise, now worth $7 billion a year, through pricing and lawsuits.
articles.abstract: As a looming battle with Roche approaches, Amgen is preparing to defend its anemia franchise, now worth $7 billion a year, through pricing and lawsuits.
articles.lead_paragraph: At first, the Amgen sales director chatted about the hot weather when she called on a small Baltimore chain of kidney dialysis clinics. Then, according to the chain’s chief financial officer, she delivered a chilling warning.

articles.headline: Record Price of Oil Raises New Fears
articles.snippet: As $100-a-barrel oil is no longer such a distant prospect, some analysts predicted that motorists would see sharply higher gasoline prices by Thanksgiving.
articles.abstract: As $100-a-barrel oil is no longer such a distant prospect, some analysts predicted that motorists would see sharply higher gasoline prices by Thanksgiving.
articles.lead_paragraph: The price of oil jumped to yet another record yesterday, sparking predictions that motorists would see sharply higher gasoline prices by Thanksgiving — and fears that $100-a-barrel oil is no longer such a distant prospect.

articles.headline: Banks’ Safety Net for Lenders May Have Holes in It
articles.snippet: Analysts said that the new fund of last resort recently created by three large banks will not address some of the more intractable problems of mortgage securities.
articles.abstract: Analysts said that the new fund of last resort recently created by three large banks will not address some of the more intractable problems of mortgage securities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Suppose your credit card companies demanded that you pay off your balances in full by month’s end and that you not use your cards for the foreseeable future.

articles.headline: Global Warming Starts to Divide G.O.P. Contenders
articles.snippet: The debate among Republicans is largely not about whether people are warming the planet, but about how to deal with it.
articles.abstract: The debate among Republicans is largely not about whether people are warming the planet, but about how to deal with it.
articles.lead_paragraph: While many conservative commentators and editorialists have mocked concerns about climate change, a different reality is emerging among Republican presidential contenders. It is a near-unanimous recognition among the leaders of the threat posed by global warming.

articles.headline: Safety Fears on No-Pilot Airplanes
articles.snippet: The Federal Aviation Administration is concerned that no-pilot airplanes cannot watch out for other air traffic the way a human pilot does.
articles.abstract: The Federal Aviation Administration is concerned that no-pilot airplanes cannot watch out for other air traffic the way a human pilot does.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 — The plane crashed near Nogales, Ariz., because the pilot had turned off the engine and never noticed, the National Transportation Safety Board ruled Tuesday.

articles.headline: Cablevision Buyout Deal Is Imperiled
articles.snippet: The Dolan family’s $10.6 billion proposed buyout of Cablevision was on the edge of collapse after it emerged that its biggest shareholder threatened to vote against the deal.
articles.abstract: The Dolan family’s $10.6 billion proposed buyout of Cablevision was on the edge of collapse after it emerged that its biggest shareholder threatened to vote against the deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Dolan family’s $10.6 billion proposed buyout of Cablevision Systems was teetering on the edge of collapse last night after it emerged that its largest shareholder was threatening to vote against the deal.

articles.headline: Silicon Valley Start-Ups Awash in Dollars, Again
articles.snippet: Investors, showing symptoms of irrational exuberance, seem to have forgotten the dot-com bust.
articles.abstract: Investors, showing symptoms of irrational exuberance, seem to have forgotten the dot-com bust.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16 — Silicon Valley’s math is getting fuzzy again.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Matt Richtel

articles.headline: Lifers as Teenagers, Now Seeking Second Chance
articles.snippet: The U.S. stands alone in the world in convicting adolescents as adults and sentencing them to life.
articles.abstract: The U.S. stands alone in the world in convicting adolescents as adults and sentencing them to life.
articles.lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — In December, the United Nations took up a resolution calling for the abolition of life imprisonment without the possibility of parole for children and young teenagers. The vote was 185 to 1, with the United States the lone dissenter.
